Noise-Robust and Resource-Efficient ADMM-based Federated Learning

Ehsan Lari, , Reza Arablouei, Vinay Chakravarthi Gogineni, , and Stefan Werner This work was supported by the Research Council of Norway. Parts of this work have been presented at the 2023 IEEE Statistical Signal Processing Workshop (SSP) [DOI: 10.1109/SSP53291.2023.10208024] and the 2023 Asia Pacific Signal and Information Processing Association Annual Summit and Conference (APSIPA ASC) [DOI: 10.1109/APSIPAASC58517.2023.10317446]. (Corresponding author: Ehsan Lari.)Ehsan Lari and Stefan Werner are with the Department of Electronic Systems, Norwegian University of Science and Technology, 7491 Trondheim, Norway (e-mail: {ehsan.lari, stefan.werner}@ntnu.no). Stefan Werner is also with the Department of Information and Communications Engineering, Aalto University, 00076, Finland.Reza Arablouei is with the Commonwealth Scientific and Industrial Research Organisation, Pullenvale, QLD 4069, Australia (e-mail: reza.arablouei@csiro.au).Vinay Chakravarthi Gogineni is with the SDU Applied AI and Data Science, The Maersk Mc-Kinney Moller Institute, Faculty of Engineering, University of Southern Denmark, Odense 5230, Denmark (e-mail: vigo@mmmi.sdu.dk).
Abstract

Federated learning (FL) leverages client-server communications to train global models on decentralized data. However, communication noise or errors can impair model accuracy. To address this problem, we propose a novel FL algorithm that enhances robustness against communication noise while also reducing communication load. We derive the proposed algorithm through solving the weighted least-squares (WLS) regression problem as an illustrative example. We first frame WLS regression as a distributed convex optimization problem over a federated network employing random scheduling for improved communication efficiency. We then apply the alternating direction method of multipliers (ADMM) to iteratively solve this problem. To counteract the detrimental effects of cumulative communication noise, we introduce a key modification by eliminating the dual variable and implementing a new local model update at each participating client. This subtle yet effective change results in using a single noisy global model update at each client instead of two, improving robustness against additive communication noise. Furthermore, we incorporate another modification enabling clients to continue local updates even when not selected by the server, leading to substantial performance improvements. Our theoretical analysis confirms the convergence of our algorithm in both mean and the mean-square senses, even when the server communicates with a random subset of clients over noisy links at each iteration. Numerical results validate the effectiveness of our proposed algorithm and corroborate our theoretical findings.

Index Terms:
Alternating direction method of multipliers, federated learning, noisy communication links, reduced communication, weighted least-squares.

I Introduction

The proliferation of smart devices has led to the widespread availability of big data, which has the potential to enhance decision-making processes for end-users [1, 2, 3, 4, 5]. However, leveraging this data effectively presents several challenges, particularly in terms of privacy, security, and resource management. A key issue is that data is typically stored locally on edge devices, and transferring it to a central server or the cloud raises privacy and security concerns and can lead to excessive resource utilization. Federated learning (FL) has emerged as a promising machine learning paradigm that addresses these challenges by enabling edge devices to collaboratively train a global model without sharing their locally stored data [1, 6]. FL faces two significant challenges: data heterogeneity and device heterogeneity [7]. Data heterogeneity arises from the non-independent and identically distributed (non-IID) nature of data or imbalances among client datasets used in training the global model [8, 9]. Diversity in data distribution across participants can significantly impact model convergence and performance. Additionally, device heterogeneity refers to the disparities in storage capacity, energy resources, computational power, and communication capabilities among participating clients [10, 11]. Variations in device characteristics can affect the efficiency and fairness of the FL process. Despite these challenges, FL emerges as a promising approach for managing heterogeneous data and devices in distributed learning settings.

The FL literature frequently employs the FedAvg algorithm [1] as a standard benchmark. FedAvg begins with the server broadcasting its aggregated global model to a randomly chosen subset of clients, typically over a wireless network. These clients then perform local training to refine their local models before sending the updates back to the server. The server aggregates these local models into a new global model, repeating this process until a specific convergence criterion is met. Building on FedAvg, numerous FL approaches have been developed to address various challenges inherent in distributed learning. These challenges include preserving privacy [12, 13, 14, 15, 16, 17, 18], mitigating Byzantine attacks [19, 20, 21, 22], and improving communication efficiency [23, 24, 25, 26, 27, 28]. However, many of these approaches assume ideal communication links, overlooking the potential impact of communication errors or noise [29, 30, 31, 32]. In practical deployments, the communication channels between clients and the server are often subject to noise, which can degrade model performance [33]. To address this issue, various techniques have been proposed to enhance the robustness of FL models in the presence of communication noise. While some studies focus on the uplink noise and neglect the downlink noise [34, 35], others account for noise in both communication directions [36].

In real-world scenarios, communication channels between the central server and edge devices are often imperfect, leading to noise in both uplink and downlink [37, 33, 38]. This leads to the server receiving noisy versions of local model updates and clients obtaining noisy versions of the aggregated model from the server, potentially compromising the quality of the learned model. The presence of noise in communication channels can severely impair the performance of gradient-descent-based FL algorithms. Several solutions have been proposed to address this challenge. One approach involves utilizing a new loss function that incorporates the first-order derivative as a regularizer to counteract additive noise [33]. Additionally, resilience to downlink noise can be enhanced through techniques such as digital transmission with quantization and channel coding or analog downlink transmission using uncoded global model updates [36]. Moreover, [39, 40] propose that controlling the scale of the communication signal-to-noise ratio (SNR) can help tolerate noise while maintaining the convergence rate of FedAvg. In [41], the authors utilize precoding and scaling during transmissions to mitigate the adverse effects of noisy channels, ensuring the convergence of their algorithm. While these methods show promise, they typically require additional resources on the client side. This requirement can pose challenges in practical FL applications, where clients may operate under constraints such as limited power, energy, memory, or computational capacity.

In [42, 43, 44], it is shown that the algorithms based on the alternating direction method of multipliers (ADMM) [45] can achieve convergence even in the presence of additive communication noise. This robustness positions ADMM as a promising candidate for FL applications where communication noise is a concern. However, conventional ADMM algorithms require the participation of all clients in each FL round, which may be impractical in real-world FL scenarios due to resource constraints and the heterogeneity of edge devices. Therefore, there is a pressing need for developing ADMM-based FL algorithms that can effectively cope with communication noise with minimal additional communication or computational overhead.

In this paper, we propose a new communication-efficient FL algorithm based on ADMM that is resilient against communication noise and errors in both uplink and downlink channels, without imposing any additional computational burden on participating clients. Using the weighted least-squares (WLS) regression problem as a motivating example, we develop our proposed FL algorithm by iteratively solving an aptly formulated distributed convex optimization problem via ADMM. To enhance communication efficiency, we incorporate random client scheduling, where the server selects a subset of clients during each FL iteration. To alleviate the adverse effects of link noise, we communicate a linear combination of the last two global model updates and eliminate the dual model parameters at all participating edge devices. Moreover, we enable clients to continue performing model updates, even when not scheduled for participation in any FL round. We evaluate the proposed algorithm and showcase its effectiveness through comprehensive theoretical performance analysis and numerical simulations. In summary, our main contributions are:

  • •

    We propose an ADMM-based FL algorithm that is robust to communication noise without imposing any additional computational overhead on clients.

  • •

    We employ a random client scheduling mechanism that effectively reduces the communication load during the learning process, distinguishing our approach from conventional ADMM algorithms.T In addition, to further enhance performance, we allow continual local updates at clients not selected by the server in any FL round.

  • •

    As a key advancement over the related conference precursors [46, 47], we present a rigorous first- and second-order theoretical analysis of the proposed algorithm, proving its convergence in both mean and mean-square senses, even in the presence of link noise and random scheduling. In addition, we derive the theoretical steady-state mean-square error (MSE) as a function of various parameters, including the number of participating clients in each iteration and the uplink and downlink noise variances. We validate the accuracy of our analysis through comparisons with simulation results.

The remainder of this paper is organized as follows. In section II, we provide an overview of the system model and the background for our problem. In section III, we introduce our proposed noise-robust and communication-efficient FL algorithm. In addition, we introduce a modification to allow continual local updates at clients regardless of random client scheduling to improve performance. In section IV, we evaluate the robustness of the proposed algorithm by analyzing its theoretical mean and mean-square convergence and calculating its theoretical steady-state MSE. In section V, we validate our theoretical findings through comprehensive numerical experiments, assessing algorithm performance through both theoretical predictions and numerical simulations. Finally, in section VI, we present some concluding remarks.

II Federated Learning over Noisy Channels

We consider a federated network consisting of a server and K𝐾K clients, where the clients communicate with the server over wireless channels. Each client k𝑘k has access to a local dataset denoted by 𝒟k={𝐗k,𝐲k}subscript𝒟𝑘subscript𝐗𝑘subscript𝐲𝑘{\mathcal{D}}_{k}=\{\mathbf{X}_{k},\mathbf{y}_{k}\}, which comprises a column response vector 𝐲ksubscript𝐲𝑘\mathbf{y}_{k} with dksubscript𝑑𝑘d_{k} entries, and a data matrix 𝐗ksubscript𝐗𝑘\mathbf{X}_{k} of size dk×Lsubscript𝑑𝑘𝐿d_{k}\times L. For each client k𝑘k, a linear model is employed to relate the data matrix 𝐗ksubscript𝐗𝑘\mathbf{X}_{k} to the response vector 𝐲ksubscript𝐲𝑘\mathbf{y}_{k} as

𝐲k=𝐗k​𝝎+𝝂k,subscript𝐲𝑘subscript𝐗𝑘𝝎subscript𝝂𝑘\mathbf{y}_{k}=\mathbf{X}_{k}\boldsymbol{\omega}+\boldsymbol{\nu}_{k}, (1)

where 𝝎𝝎\boldsymbol{\omega} denotes the global regression model parameter vector of size L𝐿L, and 𝝂ksubscript𝝂𝑘\boldsymbol{\nu}_{k} represents the observation noise or perturbation, which is a vector of size dksubscript𝑑𝑘d_{k} with each entry assumed to be zero-mean Gaussian.

II-A Federated Weighted Least-Squares Regression

Weighted least-squares (WLS) regression is a natural extension of least-squares regression that offers significant advantages in various signal processing applications, such as power system state estimation [48], position estimation [49], and image noise reduction [50]. In WLS, different observations are assigned weights based on their reliability, allowing the model to more accurately reflect the data when observations vary in quality. This approach can effectively mitigate the impact of less reliable data, resulting in more precise and dependable models.

In federated WLS regression, the goal is to collaboratively estimate the global model parameter vector 𝝎𝝎\boldsymbol{\omega} by minimizing a global objective function across a federated network. This is framed as a global WLS estimation problem within the FL framework as

where 𝒥k​(𝐰k)=‖𝐲k−𝐗k​𝐰k‖𝓦k2subscript𝒥𝑘subscript𝐰𝑘superscriptsubscriptnormsubscript𝐲𝑘subscript𝐗𝑘subscript𝐰𝑘subscript𝓦𝑘2{\mathcal{J}}_{k}(\mathbf{w}_{k})=\|\mathbf{y}_{k}-\mathbf{X}_{k}\mathbf{w}_{k}\|_{\boldsymbol{\mathcal{W}}_{k}}^{2} is the local objective function for estimating 𝝎𝝎\boldsymbol{\omega} at client k𝑘k, 𝓦ksubscript𝓦𝑘\boldsymbol{\mathcal{W}}_{k} is the weight matrix specific to client k𝑘k, 𝐰ksubscript𝐰𝑘\mathbf{w}_{k} is the local model estimate at client k𝑘k, and 𝐰𝐰\mathbf{w} serves as the global model estimate. II-B Dual Variable Elimination

We posit that, in the recursions (5)-(6), it is necessary to transmit a combination of the primal and dual model parameter estimates to the server to enable the aggregation that produces the global model estimate. However, the dual update information can be integrated into the primal update by judiciously selecting the initial estimates and introducing a new local primal update at clients. Accordingly, we reformulate (5)-(6) as

𝐰nsubscript𝐰𝑛\displaystyle\mathbf{w}_{n} =1K​∑k=1K𝐰k,nabsent1𝐾superscriptsubscript𝑘1𝐾subscript𝐰𝑘𝑛\displaystyle=\frac{1}{K}\sum\limits_{k=1}^{K}{\mathbf{w}}_{k,n} (9a)

by initializing with 𝐰−1=𝟎subscript𝐰10\mathbf{w}_{-1}=\mathbf{0}, 𝐳k,−1=𝟎subscript𝐳𝑘10\mathbf{z}_{k,-1}=\mathbf{0}, and 𝐰k,0=𝐰^ksubscript𝐰𝑘0subscript^𝐰𝑘\mathbf{w}_{k,0}=\widehat{\mathbf{w}}_{k}, hence eliminating the Lagrange multipliers 𝐳k,nsubscript𝐳𝑘𝑛\mathbf{z}_{k,n}. The recursion begins with clients sharing their 𝐰^ksubscript^𝐰𝑘\widehat{\mathbf{w}}_{k} with the server, which then aggregates them and broadcasts the resulting global model estimate to the clients. We further define 𝐬n=2​𝐰n−𝐰n−1subscript𝐬𝑛2subscript𝐰𝑛subscript𝐰𝑛1\mathbf{s}_{n}=2\mathbf{w}_{n}-\mathbf{w}_{n-1} and modify (9b) as

𝐰k,n+1subscript𝐰𝑘𝑛1\displaystyle\mathbf{w}_{k,n+1} =(𝐈−ρ​𝐍k)​𝐰k,n+ρ​𝐍k​𝐬n.absent𝐈𝜌subscript𝐍𝑘subscript𝐰𝑘𝑛𝜌subscript𝐍𝑘subscript𝐬𝑛\displaystyle=(\mathbf{I}-\rho\mathbf{N}_{k})\mathbf{w}_{k,n}+\rho\mathbf{N}_{k}\mathbf{s}_{n}. (10)

A key advantage of (10) over (9b) is that the linear combination of the two most recent global model estimates, required for local model updates, is performed at the server rather than by individual clients. This can significantly reduce the impact of communication noise as the combination occurs before transmission to clients.

II-C Communication Noise

Clients and the server often communicate via wireless channels, where both uplink and downlink channels are susceptible to noise. In the downlink, clients receive noisy versions of the aggregated model updates from the server. Specifically, at iteration n𝑛n, client k𝑘k receives 𝐬~k,n=𝐬n+𝜻k,nsubscript~𝐬𝑘𝑛subscript𝐬𝑛subscript𝜻𝑘𝑛\tilde{\mathbf{s}}_{k,n}=\mathbf{s}_{n}+\boldsymbol{\zeta}_{k,n} where 𝜻k,nsubscript𝜻𝑘𝑛\boldsymbol{\zeta}_{k,n} represents the downlink noise affecting the transmission In the uplink, the server receives a noisy version of each client’s local model update, i.e., 𝐰~k,n+1=𝐰k,n+1+𝜼k,nsubscript~𝐰𝑘𝑛1subscript𝐰𝑘𝑛1subscript𝜼𝑘𝑛\tilde{\mathbf{w}}_{k,n+1}=\mathbf{w}_{k,n+1}+\boldsymbol{\eta}_{k,n} where 𝜼k,nsubscript𝜼𝑘𝑛\boldsymbol{\eta}_{k,n} denotes the uplink noise for client k𝑘k at iteration n𝑛n. Considering the impact of communication noise and allowing client updates to occur before server aggregation, we obtain

III Resource-efficient FL over Noisy Channels

In this section, we introduce RERCE-Fed, our proposed FL algorithm, that is both resource-efficient and robust to communication errors.

III-A Random Scheduling

In (11), there is an implicit assumption that all clients participate in each global model update iteration. However, in FL, clients often have limited communication and computational resources. Therefore, requiring participation of all clients in every global update round can lead to significant drawbacks, such as prolonged convergence time or excessive resource utilization. To address this challenge, we enable the server to implement a mechanism known as random scheduling. This approach involves randomly selecting a subset of clients, denoted by 𝒮nsubscript𝒮𝑛{\mathcal{S}}_{n}, to participate in model aggregation at each iteration n𝑛n. We consider the cardinality of this subset, 𝒞=|𝒮n|𝒞subscript𝒮𝑛{\mathcal{C}}=|{\mathcal{S}}_{n}|, to be fixed throughout the FL process.

III-B RERCE-Fed

In our proposed algorithm, during each global iteration n𝑛n, the selected clients, k∈𝒮n𝑘subscript𝒮𝑛k\in{\mathcal{S}}_{n}, receive 𝐬~k,nsubscript~𝐬𝑘𝑛\tilde{\mathbf{s}}_{k,n} from the server and update their models. The server then receives 𝐰~k,n+1subscript~𝐰𝑘𝑛1\tilde{\mathbf{w}}_{k,n+1} from these clients and aggregates them. Subsequently, it broadcasts the most recent global update to a new set of selected clients in the next iteration. Clients not selected by the server in a given round retain their latest local update until they are selected again. Therefore, the recursions of the proposed RERCE-Fed algorithm are expressed as [46]

𝐰k,n+1subscript𝐰𝑘𝑛1\displaystyle\mathbf{w}_{k,n+1} =(𝐈−ak,n​ρ​𝐍k)​𝐰k,n+ak,n​ρ​𝐍k​𝐬~k,nabsent𝐈subscript𝑎𝑘𝑛𝜌subscript𝐍𝑘subscript𝐰𝑘𝑛subscript𝑎𝑘𝑛𝜌subscript𝐍𝑘subscript~𝐬𝑘𝑛\displaystyle=\left(\mathbf{I}-a_{k,n}\rho\mathbf{N}_{k}\right)\mathbf{w}_{k,n}+a_{k,n}\rho\mathbf{N}_{k}\tilde{\mathbf{s}}_{k,n} (12a)
𝐰n+1subscript𝐰𝑛1\displaystyle\mathbf{w}_{n+1} =1𝒞​∑k=1Kak,n​𝐰~k,n+1,absent1𝒞superscriptsubscript𝑘1𝐾subscript𝑎𝑘𝑛subscript~𝐰𝑘𝑛1\displaystyle=\frac{1}{{\mathcal{C}}}\sum\limits_{k=1}^{K}a_{k,n}\tilde{\mathbf{w}}_{k,n+1}, (12b)

where ak,nsubscript𝑎𝑘𝑛a_{k,n} is the indicator variable for random scheduling, with ak,n=1subscript𝑎𝑘𝑛1a_{k,n}=1 when client k𝑘k is selected by the server in iteration n𝑛n (i.e., k∈𝒮n𝑘subscript𝒮𝑛k\in{\mathcal{S}}_{n}) and ak,n=0subscript𝑎𝑘𝑛0a_{k,n}=0 otherwise. We summarize RERCE-Fed in Algorithm 1.

III-C RERCE-Fed with Continual Local Updates

Unlike the conventional random scheduling approach, described in section III-A, where non-selected clients refrain from local updates and their latest model estimates are not integrated into the global aggregation process, we propose a new approach where all clients, regardless of their selection status, continually update their local model estimates during each iteration. This new approach can enhance overall performance without introducing any additional communication overhead or imposing any notable increase in computational load of clients or the server, as we will demonstrate later. To implement this approach, clients store the most recent global model estimate received from the server, while the server holds the latest local model estimates received from all clients. Consequently, clients continually update their local models using the most recent global model estimate, and the server updates the global model using the latest local updates from all clients, irrespective of random scheduling. When a client is selected at iteration n𝑛n, its latest local model estimate is synchronized at the server, and the global model estimate received from the server supersedes the previous version at the client.

Therefore, the recursions of the RERCE-Fed algorithm with continual local updates are given by [47]

𝐰k,n+1subscript𝐰𝑘𝑛1\displaystyle\mathbf{w}_{k,n+1} =(𝐈−ρ​𝐍k)​𝐰k,nabsent𝐈𝜌subscript𝐍𝑘subscript𝐰𝑘𝑛\displaystyle=(\mathbf{I}-\rho\mathbf{N}_{k})\mathbf{w}_{k,n}
+ρ​𝐍k​[ak,n​𝐬~k,n+(1−ak,n)​𝐬~k,m]𝜌subscript𝐍𝑘delimited-[]subscript𝑎𝑘𝑛subscript~𝐬𝑘𝑛1subscript𝑎𝑘𝑛subscript~𝐬𝑘𝑚\displaystyle\quad+\rho\mathbf{N}_{k}\left[a_{k,n}\tilde{\mathbf{s}}_{k,n}+(1-a_{k,n})\tilde{\mathbf{s}}_{k,m}\right] (13a)
𝐰n+1subscript𝐰𝑛1\displaystyle\mathbf{w}_{n+1} =1K​∑k=1K[ak,n​𝐰~k,n+1+(1−ak,n)​𝐰~k,m],absent1𝐾superscriptsubscript𝑘1𝐾delimited-[]subscript𝑎𝑘𝑛subscript~𝐰𝑘𝑛11subscript𝑎𝑘𝑛subscript~𝐰𝑘𝑚\displaystyle=\frac{1}{K}\sum\limits_{k=1}^{K}\left[a_{k,n}\tilde{\mathbf{w}}_{k,n+1}+(1-a_{k,n})\tilde{\mathbf{w}}_{k,m}\right], (13b)

where 𝐬~k,msubscript~𝐬𝑘𝑚\tilde{\mathbf{s}}_{k,m} denotes the most recent global model estimate received from the server and stored in client k𝑘k. This estimate is utilized when the client is not selected by the server. Additionally, 𝐰~k,msubscript~𝐰𝑘𝑚\tilde{\mathbf{w}}_{k,m} represents the most recent local model estimate associated with client k𝑘k, which is stored at the server and utilized during iterations when the client is not chosen through random scheduling. Defining 𝐭k,n+1=2​𝐰k,n+1−𝐰k,nsubscript𝐭𝑘𝑛12subscript𝐰𝑘𝑛1subscript𝐰𝑘𝑛\mathbf{t}_{k,n+1}=2\mathbf{w}_{k,n+1}-\mathbf{w}_{k,n}, we can restate (13b) as

𝐬n+1subscript𝐬𝑛1\displaystyle\mathbf{s}_{n+1} =1K​∑k=1K[ak,n​𝐭~k,n+1+(1−ak,n)​𝐭~k,m].absent1𝐾superscriptsubscript𝑘1𝐾delimited-[]subscript𝑎𝑘𝑛subscript~𝐭𝑘𝑛11subscript𝑎𝑘𝑛subscript~𝐭𝑘𝑚\displaystyle=\frac{1}{K}\sum\limits_{k=1}^{K}\left[a_{k,n}\tilde{\mathbf{t}}_{k,n+1}+(1-a_{k,n})\tilde{\mathbf{t}}_{k,m}\right]. (14)

We summarize RERCE-Fed with continual local updates in Algorithm 2.

IV Performance Analysis

In this section, we analyze the performance of RERCE-Fed theoretically. We establish the convergence of the iterates 𝐰k,nsubscript𝐰𝑘𝑛\mathbf{w}_{k,n} in both mean and mean-square senses as n→∞→𝑛n\rightarrow\infty, even in the presence of noisy communication links. Given that 𝐰nsubscript𝐰𝑛\mathbf{w}_{n} represents the average of client estimates 𝐰k,nsubscript𝐰𝑘𝑛\mathbf{w}_{k,n}, its convergence follows accordingly.

To facilitate the analysis, we define the extended optimal global model as 𝐰e⋆=𝟏2​K⊗𝐰⋆superscriptsubscript𝐰𝑒⋆tensor-productsubscript12𝐾superscript𝐰⋆\mathbf{w}_{e}^{\star}=\mathbf{1}_{2K}\otimes\mathbf{w}^{\star} and the vector containing the client local model estimates as

𝐰e,n=col​{𝐰1,n,⋯,𝐰K,n,𝐰1,n−1,⋯,𝐰K,n−1},subscript𝐰𝑒𝑛colsubscript𝐰1𝑛⋯subscript𝐰𝐾𝑛subscript𝐰1𝑛1⋯subscript𝐰𝐾𝑛1\mathbf{w}_{e,n}={\rm col}\{\mathbf{w}_{1,n},\cdots,\mathbf{w}_{K,n},\mathbf{w}_{1,n-1},\cdots,\mathbf{w}_{K,n-1}\},

where 𝟏2​Ksubscript12𝐾\mathbf{1}_{2K} is the 2​K×12𝐾12K\times 1 vector of all ones, ⊗tensor-product\otimes is the Kronecker product, and col​{⋅}col⋅{\rm col}\{\cdot\} denotes column-wise stacking.

Substituting (12b) into (12a), the global recursion of the proposed algorithm can be stated as

𝐰e,n+1=𝓐n​𝐰e,n+𝜻n+𝜼n,subscript𝐰𝑒𝑛1subscript𝓐𝑛subscript𝐰𝑒𝑛subscript𝜻𝑛subscript𝜼𝑛\mathbf{w}_{e,n+1}=\boldsymbol{\mathcal{A}}_{n}\mathbf{w}_{e,n}+\boldsymbol{\zeta}_{n}+\boldsymbol{\eta}_{n}, (15)

where

𝓐n=[𝓐n,1A_n,2\hdashline​[2​p​t/2​p​t]​𝐈0],subscript𝓐𝑛delimited-[]subscript𝓐𝑛1A_n,2missing-subexpressionmissing-subexpression\hdashlinedelimited-[]2𝑝𝑡2𝑝𝑡𝐈0missing-subexpressionmissing-subexpression\boldsymbol{\mathcal{A}}_{n}=\left[\begin{array}[]{c;{2pt/2pt}c}\boldsymbol{\mathcal{A}}_{n,1}&\boldsymbol{\mathcal{A}}_{n,2}\\ \hdashline[2pt/2pt]\mathbf{I}&\mathbf{0}\end{array}\right], (16)

and the extended noise vectors 𝜻nsubscript𝜻𝑛\boldsymbol{\zeta}_{n} and 𝜼nsubscript𝜼𝑛\boldsymbol{\eta}_{n} stack the vectors

ak,n​ρ​𝐍k​𝜻k,nsubscript𝑎𝑘𝑛𝜌subscript𝐍𝑘subscript𝜻𝑘𝑛a_{k,n}\rho\mathbf{N}_{k}\boldsymbol{\zeta}_{k,n} (17)

and

ak,n​ρ𝒞​𝐍k​∑j=1K(2​aj,n−1​𝜼j,n−1−aj,n−2​𝜼j,n−2)subscript𝑎𝑘𝑛𝜌𝒞subscript𝐍𝑘superscriptsubscript𝑗1𝐾2subscript𝑎𝑗𝑛1subscript𝜼𝑗𝑛1subscript𝑎𝑗𝑛2subscript𝜼𝑗𝑛2a_{k,n}\frac{\rho}{{\mathcal{C}}}\mathbf{N}_{k}\sum\limits_{j=1}^{K}\left(2a_{j,n-1}\boldsymbol{\eta}_{j,n-1}-a_{j,n-2}\boldsymbol{\eta}_{j,n-2}\right) (18)

at their top halves, respectively, and zeros at their bottom halves. The value of 𝓐n∈ℝ2​L​K×2​L​Ksubscript𝓐𝑛superscriptℝ2𝐿𝐾2𝐿𝐾\boldsymbol{\mathcal{A}}_{n}\in\mathbb{R}^{2LK\times 2LK} depends on the iteration number n𝑛n as the server selects a random number of clients at each iteration. Its sub-matrices of size L​K×L​K𝐿𝐾𝐿𝐾LK\times LK are block matrices whose L×L𝐿𝐿L\times L blocks are calculated as

[𝓐n,1]i​isubscriptdelimited-[]subscript𝓐𝑛1𝑖𝑖\displaystyle\left[\boldsymbol{\mathcal{A}}_{n,1}\right]_{ii} =𝐈−ai,n​ρ​𝐍i+2​ai,n​ai,n−1​ρ𝒞​𝐍iabsent𝐈subscript𝑎𝑖𝑛𝜌subscript𝐍𝑖2subscript𝑎𝑖𝑛subscript𝑎𝑖𝑛1𝜌𝒞subscript𝐍𝑖\displaystyle=\mathbf{I}-a_{i,n}\rho\mathbf{N}_{i}+2a_{i,n}a_{i,n-1}\frac{\rho}{{\mathcal{C}}}\mathbf{N}_{i} (19a)
[𝓐n,1]i​jsubscriptdelimited-[]subscript𝓐𝑛1𝑖𝑗\displaystyle\left[\boldsymbol{\mathcal{A}}_{n,1}\right]_{ij} =2​ai,n​aj,n−1​ρ𝒞​𝐍i,i≠jformulae-sequenceabsent2subscript𝑎𝑖𝑛subscript𝑎𝑗𝑛1𝜌𝒞subscript𝐍𝑖𝑖𝑗\displaystyle=2a_{i,n}a_{j,n-1}\frac{\rho}{{\mathcal{C}}}\mathbf{N}_{i},\ i\neq j (19b)
[𝓐n,2]i​jsubscriptdelimited-[]subscript𝓐𝑛2𝑖𝑗\displaystyle\left[\boldsymbol{\mathcal{A}}_{n,2}\right]_{ij} =−ai,n​aj,n−2​ρ𝒞​𝐍i.absentsubscript𝑎𝑖𝑛subscript𝑎𝑗𝑛2𝜌𝒞subscript𝐍𝑖\displaystyle=-a_{i,n}a_{j,n-2}\frac{\rho}{{\mathcal{C}}}\mathbf{N}_{i}. (19c)

To make the analysis tractable, we adopt the following assumptions:

A1: The communication noise vectors of both uplink and downlink, 𝜼k,nsubscript𝜼𝑘𝑛\boldsymbol{\eta}_{k,n} and 𝜻k,n​∀k,nsubscript𝜻𝑘𝑛for-all𝑘𝑛\boldsymbol{\zeta}_{k,n}\ \forall k,n, are independently and identically distributed. In addition, they are independent of each other and all other stochastic variables.

A2: The random scheduling variables, ak,n​∀k,nsubscript𝑎𝑘𝑛for-all𝑘𝑛a_{k,n}\ \forall k,n, are independent and follow the same Bernoulli distribution with parameter a¯=𝒞K¯𝑎𝒞𝐾\bar{a}=\frac{{\mathcal{C}}}{K}, i.e., ak,n=1subscript𝑎𝑘𝑛1a_{k,n}=1 with probability a¯¯𝑎\bar{a} and ak,n=0subscript𝑎𝑘𝑛0a_{k,n}=0 with probability 1−a¯1¯𝑎1-\bar{a}.

IV-A Mean Convergence

Taking the expected value of both sides of (15), while considering A1-A2, yields

𝔼​[𝐰e,n+1]=𝓐¯​𝔼​[𝐰e,n],𝔼delimited-[]subscript𝐰𝑒𝑛1¯𝓐𝔼delimited-[]subscript𝐰𝑒𝑛\mathbb{E}[\mathbf{w}_{e,n+1}]=\bar{\boldsymbol{\mathcal{A}}}\ \mathbb{E}[\mathbf{w}_{e,n}], (20)

where

𝓐¯=𝔼​[𝓐n]=[𝐈−𝓞+2​𝓟- P\hdashline​[2​p​t/2​p​t]​𝐈0],¯𝓐𝔼delimited-[]subscript𝓐𝑛delimited-[]𝐈𝓞2𝓟- Pmissing-subexpressionmissing-subexpression\hdashlinedelimited-[]2𝑝𝑡2𝑝𝑡𝐈0missing-subexpressionmissing-subexpression\bar{\boldsymbol{\mathcal{A}}}=\mathbb{E}[\boldsymbol{\mathcal{A}}_{n}]=\left[\begin{array}[]{c;{2pt/2pt}c}\mathbf{I}-\boldsymbol{\mathcal{O}}+2\boldsymbol{\mathcal{P}}&- \boldsymbol{\mathcal{P}}\\ \hdashline[2pt/2pt]\mathbf{I}&\mathbf{0}\end{array}\right], (21)
𝓞𝓞\displaystyle\boldsymbol{\mathcal{O}} =a¯​ρ​bdiag​{𝐍1,⋯,𝐍K},absent¯𝑎𝜌bdiagsubscript𝐍1⋯subscript𝐍𝐾\displaystyle=\bar{a}\rho\ {\rm bdiag}\{\mathbf{N}_{1},\cdots,\mathbf{N}_{K}\}, (22a)
𝓟𝓟\displaystyle\boldsymbol{\mathcal{P}} =a¯​ρK​𝟏K⊺⊗bcol​{𝐍1,⋯,𝐍K},absenttensor-product¯𝑎𝜌𝐾subscriptsuperscript1⊺𝐾bcolsubscript𝐍1⋯subscript𝐍𝐾\displaystyle=\frac{\bar{a}\rho}{K}\mathbf{1}^{\intercal}_{K}\otimes{\rm bcol}\{\mathbf{N}_{1},\cdots,\mathbf{N}_{K}\}, (22b)

and bcol​{⋅}bcol⋅{\rm bcol}\{\cdot\} and bdiag​{⋅}bdiag⋅{\rm bdiag}\{\cdot\} represent block column-wise stacking and block diagonalization, respectively. Given that the initial estimate of each client is deterministic, (20) can be recursively unfolded over n𝑛n iterations as

𝔼​[𝐰e,n+1]=𝓐¯n​col​{𝐰^e,𝟎},𝔼delimited-[]subscript𝐰𝑒𝑛1superscript¯𝓐𝑛colsubscript^𝐰𝑒0\mathbb{E}[\mathbf{w}_{e,n+1}]=\bar{\boldsymbol{\mathcal{A}}}^{n}{\rm col}\{\widehat{\mathbf{w}}_{e},\mathbf{0}\}, (23)

where 𝐰^e=col​{𝐰^1,⋯,𝐰^K}subscript^𝐰𝑒colsubscript^𝐰1⋯subscript^𝐰𝐾\widehat{\mathbf{w}}_{e}={\rm col}\{\widehat{\mathbf{w}}_{1},\cdots,\widehat{\mathbf{w}}_{K}\}.

Considering (21) and (22), the matrix 𝓐¯¯𝓐\bar{\boldsymbol{\mathcal{A}}} is right-stochastic, as its block rows add up to the identity matrix, and has a spectral radius of 111 with the geometric and algebraic multiplicity of L𝐿L [42, Lemma 6(a)]. Therefore, using the Jordan canonical form 𝓐¯=𝐔𝐉𝐔−1¯𝓐superscript𝐔𝐉𝐔1\bar{\boldsymbol{\mathcal{A}}}=\mathbf{U}\mathbf{J}\mathbf{U}^{-1}, we have

𝓐¯n=𝐔𝐉n​𝐔−1superscript¯𝓐𝑛superscript𝐔𝐉𝑛superscript𝐔1\bar{\boldsymbol{\mathcal{A}}}^{n}=\mathbf{U}\mathbf{J}^{n}\mathbf{U}^{-1} (24)

and, as n→∞→𝑛n\rightarrow\infty, we obtain

𝓐¯∞=∑i=1L𝐮i​𝐯i⊺.superscript¯𝓐superscriptsubscript𝑖1𝐿subscript𝐮𝑖superscriptsubscript𝐯𝑖⊺\bar{\boldsymbol{\mathcal{A}}}^{\infty}=\sum_{i=1}^{L}\mathbf{u}_{i}\mathbf{v}_{i}^{\intercal}. (25)

where 𝐮isubscript𝐮𝑖\mathbf{u}_{i} and 𝐯i⊺superscriptsubscript𝐯𝑖⊺\mathbf{v}_{i}^{\intercal} denote the i𝑖ith right and left eigenvectors of matrix 𝓐¯¯𝓐\bar{\boldsymbol{\mathcal{A}}} corresponding to the eigenvalue 111, respectively.

The L𝐿L dominant right eigenvectors (corresponding to the eigenvalue 111) have the form

𝐮i=col​{ϵi,⋯,ϵi}∀i∈{1,⋯,L},formulae-sequencesubscript𝐮𝑖colsubscriptbold-italic-ϵ𝑖⋯subscriptbold-italic-ϵ𝑖for-all𝑖1⋯𝐿\mathbf{u}_{i}={\rm col}\{\boldsymbol{\epsilon}_{i},\cdots,\boldsymbol{\epsilon}_{i}\}\ \ \forall i\in\{1,\cdots,L\},

where ϵisubscriptbold-italic-ϵ𝑖\boldsymbol{\epsilon}_{i} denotes an L𝐿L-dimensional vector with one in its i𝑖ith entry and zero in all other entries [42, Lemma 6(b)]. Additionally, the L𝐿L dominant left eigenvectors (corresponding to the eigenvalue 111) satisfy

𝐯i⊺​𝓐¯=𝐯i⊺∀i∈{1,⋯,L}formulae-sequencesuperscriptsubscript𝐯𝑖⊺¯𝓐superscriptsubscript𝐯𝑖⊺for-all𝑖1⋯𝐿\mathbf{v}_{i}^{\intercal}\bar{\boldsymbol{\mathcal{A}}}=\mathbf{v}_{i}^{\intercal}\ \ \forall i\in\{1,\cdots,L\}

that results in

𝐯i,1⊺​(𝐈−𝓞+2​𝓟)+𝐯i,2⊺superscriptsubscript𝐯𝑖1⊺𝐈𝓞2𝓟superscriptsubscript𝐯𝑖2⊺\displaystyle\mathbf{v}_{i,1}^{\intercal}(\mathbf{I}-\boldsymbol{\mathcal{O}}+2\boldsymbol{\mathcal{P}})+\mathbf{v}_{i,2}^{\intercal} =𝐯i,1⊺absentsuperscriptsubscript𝐯𝑖1⊺\displaystyle=\mathbf{v}_{i,1}^{\intercal} (26a)
𝐯i,1⊺​𝓟+𝐯i,2⊺superscriptsubscript𝐯𝑖1⊺𝓟superscriptsubscript𝐯𝑖2⊺\displaystyle\mathbf{v}_{i,1}^{\intercal}\boldsymbol{\mathcal{P}}+\mathbf{v}_{i,2}^{\intercal} =𝟎,absent0\displaystyle=\mathbf{0}, (26b)

where 𝐯isubscript𝐯𝑖\mathbf{v}_{i} can be written as col​{𝐯i,1,𝐯i,2}colsubscript𝐯𝑖1subscript𝐯𝑖2{\rm col}\{\mathbf{v}_{i,1},\mathbf{v}_{i,2}\}. Therefore, considering 𝐯i⊺​𝐮i=1superscriptsubscript𝐯𝑖⊺subscript𝐮𝑖1\mathbf{v}_{i}^{\intercal}\mathbf{u}_{i}=1, we have

𝐯i,1⊺​(𝐈−𝓞+𝓟)superscriptsubscript𝐯𝑖1⊺𝐈𝓞𝓟\displaystyle\mathbf{v}_{i,1}^{\intercal}(\mathbf{I}-\boldsymbol{\mathcal{O}}+\boldsymbol{\mathcal{P}}) =𝐯i,1⊺absentsuperscriptsubscript𝐯𝑖1⊺\displaystyle=\mathbf{v}_{i,1}^{\intercal} (27a)
𝐯i,1⊺​(𝐈−𝓟)​𝐮i,1superscriptsubscript𝐯𝑖1⊺𝐈𝓟subscript𝐮𝑖1\displaystyle\mathbf{v}_{i,1}^{\intercal}(\mathbf{I}-\boldsymbol{\mathcal{P}})\mathbf{u}_{i,1} =1,absent1\displaystyle=1, (27b)

where 𝐮i,1subscript𝐮𝑖1\mathbf{u}_{i,1} contains the first K​L𝐾𝐿KL entries of 𝐮isubscript𝐮𝑖\mathbf{u}_{i}.

Following the same procedure as in [42, Lemma 6(c)], 𝐯i,1​∀i∈{1,⋯,L}subscript𝐯𝑖1for-all𝑖1⋯𝐿\mathbf{v}_{i,1}\ \forall i\in\{1,\cdots,L\} can be determined from (27). Subsequently, 𝐯i,2subscript𝐯𝑖2\mathbf{v}_{i,2} can be computed using (26b). Hence, we have

𝐯i,1⊺superscriptsubscript𝐯𝑖1⊺\displaystyle\mathbf{v}_{i,1}^{\intercal} =ϵi⊺2​(∑k=1K𝐗k⊺​𝓦k​𝐗k)−1​[𝐍1−1,⋯,𝐍K−1]absentsuperscriptsubscriptbold-italic-ϵ𝑖⊺2superscriptsuperscriptsubscript𝑘1𝐾superscriptsubscript𝐗𝑘⊺subscript𝓦𝑘subscript𝐗𝑘1superscriptsubscript𝐍11⋯superscriptsubscript𝐍𝐾1\displaystyle=\frac{\boldsymbol{\epsilon}_{i}^{\intercal}}{2}\left(\sum_{k=1}^{K}\mathbf{X}_{k}^{\intercal}\boldsymbol{\mathcal{W}}_{k}\mathbf{X}_{k}\right)^{-1}\left[\mathbf{N}_{1}^{-1},\cdots,\mathbf{N}_{K}^{-1}\right] (28a)
𝐯i,2⊺superscriptsubscript𝐯𝑖2⊺\displaystyle\mathbf{v}_{i,2}^{\intercal} =−𝐯i,1⊺​𝓟∀i∈{1,⋯,L}.formulae-sequenceabsentsuperscriptsubscript𝐯𝑖1⊺𝓟for-all𝑖1⋯𝐿\displaystyle=-\mathbf{v}_{i,1}^{\intercal}\boldsymbol{\mathcal{P}}\ \ \forall i\in\{1,\cdots,L\}. (28b)

limn→∞𝔼​[𝐰e,n]=∑i=1L𝐮i​𝐯i,1⊺​𝐰^esubscript→𝑛𝔼delimited-[]subscript𝐰𝑒𝑛superscriptsubscript𝑖1𝐿subscript𝐮𝑖superscriptsubscript𝐯𝑖1⊺subscript^𝐰𝑒\displaystyle\lim_{n\rightarrow\infty}\mathbb{E}\left[\mathbf{w}_{e,n}\right]=\sum_{i=1}^{L}\mathbf{u}_{i}\mathbf{v}_{i,1}^{\intercal}\widehat{\mathbf{w}}_{e} (29)
=∑i=1L𝐮i​ϵi⊺​[(∑k=1K𝐗k⊺​𝓦k​𝐗k)−1​∑k=1K𝐗k⊺​𝓦k​𝐲k]=𝐰e⋆.absentsuperscriptsubscript𝑖1𝐿subscript𝐮𝑖superscriptsubscriptbold-italic-ϵ𝑖⊺delimited-[]superscriptsuperscriptsubscript𝑘1𝐾superscriptsubscript𝐗𝑘⊺subscript𝓦𝑘subscript𝐗𝑘1superscriptsubscript𝑘1𝐾superscriptsubscript𝐗𝑘⊺subscript𝓦𝑘subscript𝐲𝑘superscriptsubscript𝐰𝑒⋆\displaystyle=\sum_{i=1}^{L}\mathbf{u}_{i}\boldsymbol{\epsilon}_{i}^{\intercal}\left[\left(\sum_{k=1}^{K}\mathbf{X}_{k}^{\intercal}\boldsymbol{\mathcal{W}}_{k}\mathbf{X}_{k}\right)^{-1}\sum_{k=1}^{K}\mathbf{X}_{k}^{\intercal}\boldsymbol{\mathcal{W}}_{k}\mathbf{y}_{k}\right]=\mathbf{w}_{e}^{\star}.

Therefore, the RERCE-Fed algorithm is unbiased and the proof for mean convergence is complete.

IV-B Mean-Square Convergence

Let us define the deviation vector as 𝐰~e,n=𝐰e,n−𝐰e⋆subscript~𝐰𝑒𝑛subscript𝐰𝑒𝑛superscriptsubscript𝐰𝑒⋆\tilde{\mathbf{w}}_{e,n}={\mathbf{w}}_{e,n}-\mathbf{w}_{e}^{\star}. Since 𝓐nsubscript𝓐𝑛\boldsymbol{\mathcal{A}}_{n} is block right-stochastic, i.e., its block rows add up to the identity matrix, we have 𝓐n​𝐰e⋆=𝐰e⋆subscript𝓐𝑛superscriptsubscript𝐰𝑒⋆superscriptsubscript𝐰𝑒⋆\boldsymbol{\mathcal{A}}_{n}\mathbf{w}_{e}^{\star}=\mathbf{w}_{e}^{\star}. Therefore, by defining the weighted norm-square of 𝐰~e,nsubscript~𝐰𝑒𝑛\tilde{\mathbf{w}}_{e,n} as ‖𝐰~e,n‖𝚺2=𝐰~e,n⊺​𝚺​𝐰~e,nsuperscriptsubscriptnormsubscript~𝐰𝑒𝑛𝚺2subscriptsuperscript~𝐰⊺𝑒𝑛𝚺subscript~𝐰𝑒𝑛\|\tilde{\mathbf{w}}_{e,n}\|_{\boldsymbol{\Sigma}}^{2}=\tilde{\mathbf{w}}^{\intercal}_{e,n}{\boldsymbol{\Sigma}}\tilde{\mathbf{w}}_{e,n}, where 𝚺𝚺\boldsymbol{\Sigma} is an arbitrary positive semi-definite matrix, we obtain the variance relation as

𝔼𝔼\displaystyle\mathbb{E} [‖𝐰~e,n+1‖𝚺2]delimited-[]superscriptsubscriptnormsubscript~𝐰𝑒𝑛1𝚺2\displaystyle\left[\|\tilde{\mathbf{w}}_{e,n+1}\|_{\boldsymbol{\Sigma}}^{2}\right]
=𝔼​[‖𝐰~e,n‖𝚺′2]+𝔼​[𝜻n⊺​𝚺​𝜻n]+𝔼​[𝜼n⊺​𝚺​𝜼n],absent𝔼delimited-[]superscriptsubscriptnormsubscript~𝐰𝑒𝑛superscript𝚺′2𝔼delimited-[]subscriptsuperscript𝜻⊺𝑛𝚺subscript𝜻𝑛𝔼delimited-[]superscriptsubscript𝜼𝑛⊺𝚺subscript𝜼𝑛\displaystyle=\mathbb{E}\left[\|\tilde{\mathbf{w}}_{e,n}\|_{\boldsymbol{\Sigma}^{\prime}}^{2}\right]+\mathbb{E}\left[\boldsymbol{\zeta}^{\intercal}_{n}{\boldsymbol{\Sigma}}{\boldsymbol{\zeta}}_{n}\right]+\mathbb{E}\left[\boldsymbol{\eta}_{n}^{\intercal}{\boldsymbol{\Sigma}}\boldsymbol{\eta}_{n}\right], (30)

where the cross terms vanish as they are independent and uncorrelated with one another and all other variables. The matrix 𝚺′superscript𝚺′{\boldsymbol{\Sigma}^{\prime}} is given by

We can describe the relationship between 𝚺′superscript𝚺′\boldsymbol{\Sigma}^{\prime} and 𝚺𝚺\boldsymbol{\Sigma} as 𝝈′=bvec​{𝚺′}=𝓠​𝝈superscript𝝈bold-′bvecsuperscript𝚺′𝓠𝝈\boldsymbol{\sigma^{\prime}}={\rm bvec}\{\boldsymbol{\Sigma}^{\prime}\}={\boldsymbol{\mathcal{Q}}}\boldsymbol{\sigma}, where 𝓠=𝔼​[𝓐n⊺⊗b𝓐n⊺]𝓠𝔼delimited-[]subscripttensor-product𝑏superscriptsubscript𝓐𝑛⊺superscriptsubscript𝓐𝑛⊺{\boldsymbol{\mathcal{Q}}}=\mathbb{E}[{\boldsymbol{\mathcal{A}}}_{n}^{\intercal}\otimes_{b}{\boldsymbol{\mathcal{A}}}_{n}^{\intercal}] and 𝝈=bvec​{𝚺}𝝈bvec𝚺\boldsymbol{\sigma}={\rm bvec}\{\boldsymbol{\Sigma}\}. Here, ⊗bsubscripttensor-product𝑏\otimes_{b} is the block Kronecker product (Tracy–Singh product [53]) and bvec​{⋅}bvec⋅{\rm bvec}\{\cdot\} denotes the block vectorization operation [54]. We evaluate 𝓠𝓠{\boldsymbol{\mathcal{Q}}} in Appendix A.

Using the relationship between the matrix trace operator, denoted by tr​(⋅)tr⋅{\rm tr}(\cdot), and the block Kronecker product, we evaluate the second term on the right-hand side (RHS) of (IV-B) as

where ϕ=bvec​{𝔼​[𝜻n​𝜻n⊺]}bold-italic-ϕbvec𝔼delimited-[]subscript𝜻𝑛subscriptsuperscript𝜻⊺𝑛\boldsymbol{\phi}={\rm bvec}\{\mathbb{E}[\boldsymbol{\zeta}_{n}{\boldsymbol{\zeta}}^{\intercal}_{n}]\},

𝔼​[𝜻n​𝜻n⊺]=a¯​ρ2​bdiag​{σζ12​𝐍12,⋯,σζK2​𝐍K2,𝟎,⋯,𝟎⏟K},𝔼delimited-[]subscript𝜻𝑛subscriptsuperscript𝜻⊺𝑛¯𝑎superscript𝜌2bdiagsubscriptsuperscript𝜎2subscript𝜁1superscriptsubscript𝐍12⋯subscriptsuperscript𝜎2subscript𝜁𝐾superscriptsubscript𝐍𝐾2subscript⏟0⋯0𝐾\mathbb{E}[\boldsymbol{\zeta}_{n}{\boldsymbol{\zeta}}^{\intercal}_{n}]=\bar{a}\rho^{2}{\rm bdiag}\{\sigma^{2}_{\zeta_{1}}\mathbf{N}_{1}^{2},\cdots,\sigma^{2}_{\zeta_{K}}\mathbf{N}_{K}^{2},\underbrace{\mathbf{0},\cdots,\mathbf{0}}_{K}\}, (33)

and σζk2subscriptsuperscript𝜎2subscript𝜁𝑘\sigma^{2}_{\zeta_{k}} is the variance of the downlink noise for client k𝑘k.

Following a similar procedure, we evaluate the third term on the RHS of (IV-B) as

𝔼​[𝜼n⊺​𝚺​𝜼n]=tr​(𝔼​[𝜼n​𝜼n⊺]​𝚺)=𝝋⊺​𝝈,𝔼delimited-[]superscriptsubscript𝜼𝑛⊺𝚺subscript𝜼𝑛tr𝔼delimited-[]subscript𝜼𝑛subscriptsuperscript𝜼⊺𝑛𝚺superscript𝝋⊺𝝈\displaystyle\mathbb{E}[\boldsymbol{\eta}_{n}^{\intercal}{\boldsymbol{\Sigma}}\boldsymbol{\eta}_{n}]={\rm tr}\big{(}\mathbb{E}[\boldsymbol{\eta}_{n}{\boldsymbol{\eta}}^{\intercal}_{n}]\boldsymbol{\Sigma}\big{)}=\boldsymbol{\varphi}^{\intercal}\boldsymbol{\sigma}, (34)

where 𝝋=bvec​{𝔼​[𝜼n​𝜼n⊺]}𝝋bvec𝔼delimited-[]subscript𝜼𝑛subscriptsuperscript𝜼⊺𝑛\boldsymbol{\varphi}={\rm bvec}\{\mathbb{E}[\boldsymbol{\eta}_{n}{\boldsymbol{\eta}}^{\intercal}_{n}]\},

𝔼​[𝜼n​𝜼n⊺]=5​ρ2K2​∑k=1Kσηk2​bdiag​{𝐍12,⋯,𝐍K2,𝟎,⋯,𝟎⏟K},𝔼delimited-[]subscript𝜼𝑛subscriptsuperscript𝜼⊺𝑛5superscript𝜌2superscript𝐾2superscriptsubscript𝑘1𝐾superscriptsubscript𝜎subscript𝜂𝑘2bdiagsuperscriptsubscript𝐍12⋯superscriptsubscript𝐍𝐾2subscript⏟0⋯0𝐾\mathbb{E}[\boldsymbol{\eta}_{n}{\boldsymbol{\eta}}^{\intercal}_{n}]=\frac{5\rho^{2}}{K^{2}}\sum_{k=1}^{K}\sigma_{\eta_{k}}^{2}{\rm bdiag}\{\mathbf{N}_{1}^{2},\cdots,\mathbf{N}_{K}^{2},\underbrace{\mathbf{0},\cdots,\mathbf{0}}_{K}\}, (35)

and σηk2superscriptsubscript𝜎subscript𝜂𝑘2\sigma_{\eta_{k}}^{2} is the variance of the uplink noise for client k𝑘k. Note that in (35), 𝔼​[ai,n​aj,n]≪1​∀i≠jmuch-less-than𝔼delimited-[]subscript𝑎𝑖𝑛subscript𝑎𝑗𝑛1for-all𝑖𝑗\mathbb{E}[a_{i,n}a_{j,n}]\ll 1\ \forall i\neq j, and can be neglected.

Utilizing the above results, we can write the global recursion for the weighted mean-squared error (MSE) of RERCE-Fed as

𝔼𝔼\displaystyle\mathbb{E} [‖𝐰~e,n+1‖bvec−1​{𝝈}2]delimited-[]superscriptsubscriptnormsubscript~𝐰𝑒𝑛1superscriptbvec1𝝈2\displaystyle\left[\|\tilde{\mathbf{w}}_{e,n+1}\|_{{\rm bvec}^{-1}\{\boldsymbol{\sigma}\}}^{2}\right]
=𝔼​[‖𝐰~e,n‖bvec−1​{𝓠​𝝈}2]+ϕ⊺​𝝈+𝝋⊺​𝝈.absent𝔼delimited-[]superscriptsubscriptnormsubscript~𝐰𝑒𝑛superscriptbvec1𝓠𝝈2superscriptbold-italic-ϕ⊺𝝈superscript𝝋⊺𝝈\displaystyle=\mathbb{E}\left[\|\tilde{\mathbf{w}}_{e,n}\|_{{\rm bvec}^{-1}\{{\boldsymbol{\mathcal{Q}}}\boldsymbol{\sigma}\}}^{2}\right]+\boldsymbol{\phi}^{\intercal}\boldsymbol{\sigma}+\boldsymbol{\varphi}^{\intercal}\boldsymbol{\sigma}. (36)

By defining 𝝍=ϕ+𝝋𝝍bold-italic-ϕ𝝋\boldsymbol{\psi}=\boldsymbol{\phi}+\boldsymbol{\varphi} and iterating (IV-B) backward to n=1𝑛1n=1, we obtain

=𝔼​[‖𝐰~e,1‖bvec−1​{𝓠n​𝝈}2]+𝝍⊺​∑i=0n−1𝓠i​𝝈.absent𝔼delimited-[]superscriptsubscriptnormsubscript~𝐰𝑒1superscriptbvec1superscript𝓠𝑛𝝈2superscript𝝍⊺superscriptsubscript𝑖0𝑛1superscript𝓠𝑖𝝈\displaystyle=\mathbb{E}\left[\|\tilde{\mathbf{w}}_{e,1}\|_{{\rm bvec}^{-1}\{{\boldsymbol{\mathcal{Q}}}^{n}\boldsymbol{\sigma}\}}^{2}\right]+\boldsymbol{\psi}^{\intercal}\sum_{i=0}^{n-1}{\boldsymbol{\mathcal{Q}}}^{i}\boldsymbol{\sigma}. (37)

Using the Jordan canonical form of 𝓠𝓠{\boldsymbol{\mathcal{Q}}}, we have

𝓠i=𝓤​𝓙i​𝓤−1=∑ℓ=14​L2​K2μℓi​𝒖ℓ​𝒗ℓ⊺,superscript𝓠𝑖𝓤superscript𝓙𝑖superscript𝓤1superscriptsubscriptℓ14superscript𝐿2superscript𝐾2superscriptsubscript𝜇ℓ𝑖subscript𝒖ℓsuperscriptsubscript𝒗ℓ⊺\displaystyle{\boldsymbol{\mathcal{Q}}}^{i}=\boldsymbol{\mathcal{U}}\boldsymbol{\mathcal{J}}^{i}\boldsymbol{\mathcal{U}}^{-1}=\sum_{\ell=1}^{4L^{2}K^{2}}\mu_{\ell}^{i}\boldsymbol{u}_{\ell}\boldsymbol{v}_{\ell}^{\intercal}, (38)

where μℓsubscript𝜇ℓ\mu_{\ell}, 𝒖ℓsubscript𝒖ℓ\boldsymbol{u}_{\ell} and 𝒗ℓsubscript𝒗ℓ\boldsymbol{v}_{\ell} denote the ℓℓ\ellth eigenvalue of 𝓠𝓠\boldsymbol{\mathcal{Q}} and its corresponding right and left eigenvectors, respectively. In Appendix B, we show that the spectral radius of 𝓠𝓠\boldsymbol{\mathcal{Q}} is one with the geometric and algebraic multiplicity of L2superscript𝐿2L^{2}, i.e., μℓ=1​∀ℓ∈{1,…,L2}subscript𝜇ℓ1for-allℓ1…superscript𝐿2\mu_{\ell}=1\ \forall\ell\in\{1,\dots,L^{2}\}.

Proof: See Appendix C.

IV-C Steady-State Mean-Square Error

Setting 𝝈=bvec​{𝐈2​K​L}𝝈bvecsubscript𝐈2𝐾𝐿\boldsymbol{\sigma}={\rm bvec}\{\mathbf{I}_{2KL}\}, letting n→∞→𝑛n\rightarrow\infty on both sides of (IV-B), and using Proposition 1, we compute the steady-state MSE of RERCE-Fed, denoted by ℰℰ{\mathcal{E}}, as

ℰℰ\displaystyle{\mathcal{E}} =limn→∞𝔼​[𝐰~e,n⊺​𝐰~e,n]absentsubscript→𝑛𝔼delimited-[]superscriptsubscript~𝐰𝑒𝑛⊺subscript~𝐰𝑒𝑛\displaystyle=\lim_{n\to\infty}\mathbb{E}\left[\tilde{\mathbf{w}}_{e,n}^{\intercal}\tilde{\mathbf{w}}_{e,n}\right]
=𝐰~e,1⊺​𝚺∞​𝐰~e,1⏟ℰν+∑ℓ=L2+14​L2​K2(1−μℓ)−1​𝝍⊺​𝒖ℓ​𝒗ℓ⊺​𝝈⏟ℰψ,absentsubscript⏟superscriptsubscript~𝐰𝑒1⊺subscript𝚺subscript~𝐰𝑒1subscriptℰ𝜈subscript⏟superscriptsubscriptℓsuperscript𝐿214superscript𝐿2superscript𝐾2superscript1subscript𝜇ℓ1superscript𝝍⊺subscript𝒖ℓsuperscriptsubscript𝒗ℓ⊺𝝈subscriptℰ𝜓\displaystyle=\underbrace{\tilde{\mathbf{w}}_{e,1}^{\intercal}\boldsymbol{\Sigma}_{\infty}\tilde{\mathbf{w}}_{e,1}}_{{\mathcal{E}}_{\nu}}+\underbrace{\sum_{\ell=L^{2}+1}^{4L^{2}K^{2}}\left(1-\mu_{\ell}\right)^{-1}\boldsymbol{\psi}^{\intercal}\boldsymbol{u}_{\ell}\boldsymbol{v}_{\ell}^{\intercal}\boldsymbol{\sigma}}_{{\mathcal{E}}_{\psi}}, (40)

where

𝚺∞subscript𝚺\displaystyle\boldsymbol{\Sigma}_{\infty} =bvec−1​{𝓠∞​𝝈}absentsuperscriptbvec1superscript𝓠𝝈\displaystyle={\rm bvec}^{-1}\left\{{\boldsymbol{\mathcal{Q}}}^{\infty}\boldsymbol{\sigma}\right\}
=bvec−1​{∑ℓ=1L2𝒖ℓ​𝒗ℓ⊺​bvec​{𝐈2​K​L}}.absentsuperscriptbvec1superscriptsubscriptℓ1superscript𝐿2subscript𝒖ℓsuperscriptsubscript𝒗ℓ⊺bvecsubscript𝐈2𝐾𝐿\displaystyle={\rm bvec}^{-1}\left\{\sum\limits_{\ell=1}^{L^{2}}\boldsymbol{u}_{\ell}\boldsymbol{v}_{\ell}^{\intercal}{\rm bvec}\{\mathbf{I}_{2KL}\}\right\}. (41)

Remark 1: The observation noise 𝝂ksubscript𝝂𝑘\boldsymbol{\nu}_{k} in (1) and the initial client estimates 𝐰k,0subscript𝐰𝑘0\mathbf{w}_{k,0} affect the first term on the RHS of (IV-C), ℰνsubscriptℰ𝜈{\mathcal{E}}_{\nu}, resulting in a noise floor. Additionally, scheduling parameters, including the client participation probability and the number of participating clients in each iteration, along with the penalty parameter, the number of clients, the local data at each client, and the variance of noise in the uplink and downlink communications impact the second term on the RHS of (IV-C), ℰψsubscriptℰ𝜓{\mathcal{E}}_{\psi}. We will explore these factors further through simulations in section V-C.

V Simulation Results

In this section, we conduct several numerical experiments to evaluate the performance of the proposed algorithm and validate our theoretical findings. We consider a federated network consisting of K𝐾K clients. Each client has non-IID data {𝐗k,𝐲k}subscript𝐗𝑘subscript𝐲𝑘\{\mathbf{X}_{k},\mathbf{y}_{k}\}, where the entries of 𝐗ksubscript𝐗𝑘\mathbf{X}_{k} are drawn from a normal distribution 𝒩​(μk,σk2)𝒩subscript𝜇𝑘superscriptsubscript𝜎𝑘2{\mathcal{N}}(\mu_{k},\sigma_{k}^{2}) with μk∈𝒰​(−0.5,0.5)subscript𝜇𝑘𝒰0.50.5\mu_{k}\in{\mathcal{U}}(-0.5,0.5) and σk2∈𝒰​(0.5,1.5)superscriptsubscript𝜎𝑘2𝒰0.51.5\sigma_{k}^{2}\in{\mathcal{U}}(0.5,1.5). Here, 𝒰​(⋅,⋅)𝒰⋅⋅{\mathcal{U}}(\cdot,\cdot) denotes a uniform distribution with the specified lower and upper bounds. The local data size for each client is randomly selected from a uniform distribution, i.e., dk∈𝒰​(50,90)subscript𝑑𝑘𝒰5090d_{k}\in{\mathcal{U}}(50,90). We set the weight matrices at each client k𝑘k to the inverse covariance matrix of 𝐲ksubscript𝐲𝑘\mathbf{y}_{k}, i.e., 𝓦k=𝔼​[(𝐲k−𝔼​[𝐲k])​(𝐲k−𝔼​[𝐲k])⊺]−1subscript𝓦𝑘𝔼superscriptdelimited-[]subscript𝐲𝑘𝔼delimited-[]subscript𝐲𝑘superscriptsubscript𝐲𝑘𝔼delimited-[]subscript𝐲𝑘⊺1\boldsymbol{\mathcal{W}}_{k}=\mathbb{E}[\left(\mathbf{y}_{k}-\mathbb{E}[\mathbf{y}_{k}]\right)\left(\mathbf{y}_{k}-\mathbb{E}[\mathbf{y}_{k}]\right)^{\intercal}]^{-1}.

The local data is related as per (1) given the model parameter vector 𝝎𝝎\boldsymbol{\omega} with its entries drawn from a normal distribution 𝒩​(0,1)𝒩01{\mathcal{N}}(0,1). The observation noise 𝝂ksubscript𝝂𝑘\boldsymbol{\nu}_{k} for each client is zero-mean IID Gaussian with variance σνk2superscriptsubscript𝜎subscript𝜈𝑘2\sigma_{\nu_{k}}^{2}. The additive noise in both the uplink and downlink channels is zero-mean IID Gaussian with variances σηk2subscriptsuperscript𝜎2subscript𝜂𝑘\sigma^{2}_{\eta_{k}} and σζk2subscriptsuperscript𝜎2subscript𝜁𝑘\sigma^{2}_{\zeta_{k}}, respectively. We set the penalty parameter as ρ=1𝜌1\rho=1. The server randomly selects a subset of 𝒞𝒞{\mathcal{C}} clients with uniform probability in each iteration. We evaluate the algorithm performance on the client side via the normalized MSE (NMSE) defined at iteration n𝑛n as

1K​∑k=1K‖𝐰k,n−𝐰⋆‖22‖𝐰⋆‖22.1𝐾superscriptsubscript𝑘1𝐾superscriptsubscriptnormsubscript𝐰𝑘𝑛superscript𝐰⋆22superscriptsubscriptnormsuperscript𝐰⋆22\frac{1}{K}\sum\limits_{k=1}^{K}\frac{\|\mathbf{w}_{k,n}-\mathbf{w}^{\star}\|_{2}^{2}}{\|\mathbf{w}^{\star}\|_{2}^{2}}. (42)

We average the NMSE learning curves over 100100100 independent trials to obtain our simulation results.

We present the results of our numerical experiments in four subsections. In the first subsection, we evaluate the performance of the proposed RERCE-Fed algorithm in comparison to its predecessors. In the second subsection, we evaluate the performance of RERCE-Fed with continual local updates and compare it with RERCE-Fed without continual local updates. In the last subsection, we corroborate our theoretical findings by demonstrating mean convergence and comparing theoretical predictions with simulation results, confirming the accuracy of our theoretical expression for MSE of RERCE-Fed.

V-A Performance of RERCE-Fed

In our first experiment, we simulate the algorithms described by (5)-(6) and (10) to solve the considered WLS problem. We run these simulations with K=100𝐾100K=100 clients, model parameter vector size of L=128𝐿128L=128, and link noise variance of σηk2=σζk2=6.25×10−4subscriptsuperscript𝜎2subscript𝜂𝑘subscriptsuperscript𝜎2subscript𝜁𝑘6.25superscript104\sigma^{2}_{\eta_{k}}=\sigma^{2}_{\zeta_{k}}=6.25\times 10^{-4}. All clients participate in the FL process, i.e., 𝒞=K=100𝒞𝐾100{\mathcal{C}}=K=100. The corresponding learning curves are shown in Fig. 1. We observe that (10) exhibits a 7​d​B7dB7{\rm dB} improvement over (5)-(6) in the presence of noisy communication links when all clients are involved in each iteration of the FL process.

In our second experiment, we examine the performance of (5)-(6) and (10) under similar conditions as the first experiment, but with the server randomly selecting a subset of clients to participate in each iteration. We simulate (5)-(6) with 𝒞=4𝒞4{\mathcal{C}}=4 and (10) with 𝒞∈{4,75,90}𝒞47590{\mathcal{C}}\in\{4,75,90\}. The corresponding learning curves are shown in Fig. 2. Unlike the first experiment, Fig. 2 illustrates that (10) fails to converge due to error accumulation, even when a majority of clients participate in every FL round, as observed for 𝒞∈{75,90}𝒞7590{\mathcal{C}}\in\{75,90\}. Additionally, the performance of (5)-(6) degrades significantly when only a small subset of clients participate in each FL round. Consequently, both (5)-(6) and (10) exhibit an inability to cope with additive noise in communication links when the server selects only a subset of clients in each iteration.

In our third experiment, we assess the performance of the proposed RERCE-Fed algorithm in the presence of link noise and random client scheduling by the server to enhance communication efficiency. We simulate RERCE-Fed with K=100𝐾100K=100 clients, L=128𝐿128L=128, link noise variance of σηk2=σζk2=6.25×10−4subscriptsuperscript𝜎2subscript𝜂𝑘subscriptsuperscript𝜎2subscript𝜁𝑘6.25superscript104\sigma^{2}_{\eta_{k}}=\sigma^{2}_{\zeta_{k}}=6.25\times 10^{-4}, and different numbers of participating clients 𝒞∈{4,10,25}𝒞41025{\mathcal{C}}\in\{4,10,25\}. The corresponding learning curves are depicted in Fig. 3. As shown in Fig. 3, RERCE-Fed exhibits robustness against communication noise, even when only a subset of clients participate in each FL round, a contrast to the results observed with (5)-(6) and (10) in the second experiment. Another important observation from Fig. 3 is the trade-off between the number of participating clients 𝒞𝒞{\mathcal{C}} and the performance and convergence rate of RERCE-Fed. Specifically, increasing the number of participating clients leads to faster convergence and lower NMSE. However, this benefit diminishes once 𝒞≥10𝒞10{\mathcal{C}}\geq 10, as the performance of RERCE-Fed with 𝒞≥10𝒞10{\mathcal{C}}\geq 10 approaches that of the scenario where all clients participate in each FL round. This implies that RERCE-Fed can achieve accurate model parameter estimation while making more efficient use of available communication resources, even in the presence of noisy communication links.

V-B Performance of RERCE-Fed with Continual Local Updates

In our fourth experiment, we compare the performance of RERCE-Fed with and without continual local updates by plotting their corresponding learning curves given different numbers of participating clients and link noise variances. We present the results in Figs. 4-6. The number of clients selected at each iteration is 𝒞∈{4,10,25}𝒞41025{\mathcal{C}}\in\{4,10,25\}, and the link noise variances are σηk2=σζk2∈{6.25×10−4,10−2}subscriptsuperscript𝜎2subscript𝜂𝑘subscriptsuperscript𝜎2subscript𝜁𝑘6.25superscript104superscript102\sigma^{2}_{\eta_{k}}=\sigma^{2}_{\zeta_{k}}\in\{6.25\times 10^{-4},10^{-2}\}. From these figures, we observe that RERCE-Fed with continual local updates consistently exhibits robustness against communication noise, even when only a small subset of clients participate in every FL round. In addition, RERCE-Fed with continual local updates significantly outperforms its counterpart without continual local updates in all considered scenarios. These results indicate that allowing clients to continually update their local models, even when not selected by the server, leads to a substantial improvement in steady-state NMSE without adversely impacting the convergence rate. Additionally, as anticipated, increasing the link noise variance results in performance degradation.

V-C Comparison of Theory and Experiment

In our fifth experiment, we demonstrate the mean convergence of RERCE-Fed. We simulate RERCE-Fed with K=6𝐾6K=6 clients, L=6𝐿6L=6, and link noise variances σηk2=σζk2=10−4subscriptsuperscript𝜎2subscript𝜂𝑘subscriptsuperscript𝜎2subscript𝜁𝑘superscript104\sigma^{2}_{\eta_{k}}=\sigma^{2}_{\zeta_{k}}=10^{-4}. In addition, the server randomly selects 𝒞=3𝒞3{\mathcal{C}}=3 clients in each iteration. In Fig. 7, we plot the squared ℓ2subscriptℓ2\ell_{2}-norm of the global model parameter bias estimated for different numbers of Monte Carlo (MC) runs, denoted by ℳℳ{\mathcal{M}}, specifically 1L​‖1ℳ​∑i=1ℳ𝐰n(i)−𝐰⋆‖221𝐿superscriptsubscriptnorm1ℳsuperscriptsubscript𝑖1ℳsuperscriptsubscript𝐰𝑛𝑖superscript𝐰⋆22\frac{1}{L}\|\frac{1}{{\mathcal{M}}}\sum_{i=1}^{{\mathcal{M}}}\mathbf{w}_{n}^{(i)}-\mathbf{w}^{\star}\|_{2}^{2}, where 𝐰n(i)superscriptsubscript𝐰𝑛𝑖\mathbf{w}_{n}^{(i)} is the global model parameter estimate of the i𝑖ith MC run. We can observe from Fig. 7 that the squared-norm of the multivariate bias estimate decreases log-linearly with the number of MC runs, indicating the unbiasedness shown in section IV-A.

In our sixth experiment, we validate the accuracy of our theoretical expression for the steady-state MSE of RERCE-Fed in (IV-C) and explore the impact of varying uplink and downlink noise variances, σηk2subscriptsuperscript𝜎2subscript𝜂𝑘\sigma^{2}_{\eta_{k}} and σζk2subscriptsuperscript𝜎2subscript𝜁𝑘\sigma^{2}_{\zeta_{k}}, on performance. We simulate RERCE-Fed with K=6𝐾6K=6 clients, L=6𝐿6L=6 parameters, and different values for uplink and downlink noise variances. The server randomly selects 𝒞=3𝒞3{\mathcal{C}}=3 clients in each iteration. We present the theoretical predictions of steady-sate NMSE using (IV-C) alongside the corresponding experimental values in Figs. 8-9 as functions of σηk2subscriptsuperscript𝜎2subscript𝜂𝑘\sigma^{2}_{\eta_{k}}, σζk2subscriptsuperscript𝜎2subscript𝜁𝑘\sigma^{2}_{\zeta_{k}}, and 𝒞𝒞{\mathcal{C}}. The results show a close alignment between theory and experiment. Furthermore, we observe an upward trend in the steady-state NMSE as either uplink or downlink noise variance increases.

The uplink and downlink noise variances exhibit distinct effects depending on the number of participating clients 𝒞𝒞{\mathcal{C}}. While the error induced by uplink noise remains constant, the impact of downlink noise intensifies with an increasing number of participating clients. This observation is consistent with the intuition that averaging the model parameter estimates at the server can mitigate the adverse effect of uplink noise on the performance of RERCE-Fed. However, changing 𝒞𝒞{\mathcal{C}} also affects 𝓠𝓠\boldsymbol{\mathcal{Q}}. To obtain a better understanding, we investigate the impact of 𝒞𝒞{\mathcal{C}} on the performance of RERCE-Fed in our final experiment, where we consider K=6𝐾6K=6, L=6𝐿6L=6, link noise variances σηk2=σζk2∈{6.25×10−4,10−2}subscriptsuperscript𝜎2subscript𝜂𝑘subscriptsuperscript𝜎2subscript𝜁𝑘6.25superscript104superscript102\sigma^{2}_{\eta_{k}}=\sigma^{2}_{\zeta_{k}}\in\{6.25\times 10^{-4},10^{-2}\}, and 𝒞∈{2,3,4,5,6}𝒞23456{\mathcal{C}}\in\{2,3,4,5,6\}. The results presented in Fig. 10 illustrate that increasing the number of participating clients improves the performance of RERCE-Fed. However, this improvement comes at the cost of higher resource utilization on the client side, which can be limiting in real-world FL scenarios.

VI Conclusion and Future Work

We proposed RERCE-Fed, an FL algorithm designed to effectively reduce communication load while maintaining robustness against additive communication noise or errors. By employing ADMM to solve the WLS problem, we introduced a new local model update at the clients. This innovative solution mitigates the effects of communication noise without imposing additional computational burden on clients. Furthermore, we improved the communication efficiency by randomly selecting a subset of clients to participate in each learning round. To further optimize performance, we enabled non-selected clients to continue with their local updates, resulting in a modified version of RERCE-Fed. Our theoretical analysis confirmed the convergence of RERCE-Fed in both mean and mean-square sense, even with random client scheduling and communication over noisy communication links. In addition, we derived a closed-form expression for the steady-state MSE of the RERCE-Fed algorithm. Comprehensive numerical analysis substantiated our theoretical findings and confirmed the accuracy of our theoretical predictions. As a future extension of this work, we will investigate the impact of various adversarial attacks on the performance of RERCE-Fed, including model poisoning, data poisoning, and label poisoning attacks.
